item.title: Native First Voices: A Celebration for Native American Heritage Month
item.description:
November is Native American/Alaska Native Heritage Month – a time to not only celebrate the peoples and their heritage, but to commemorate the lessons and wisdom that we have gained from their traditions and partnership. Tribal engagement and strengthening the government-to-government relationship with tribes through interagency collaboration are essential for us as an agency. It is through these collaborative efforts with those in the federal family and beyond, that we have learned a tremendous amount. We celebrated and highlighted some of the talented people we work with throughout the month of November in a Twitter series called #NativeFirstVoices.

  • #NativeFirstVoices - NAHM interviews (PDF)(13 pp, 1 MB)
    November is Native American/Alaska Native Heritage Month – a time not only to celebrate the peoples and their heritage, but to commemorate the lessons and wisdom that we have gained from their traditions and partnership. We celebrated and highlighted some of the talented people we work with throughout the month of November 2016 in a series called, #NativeFirstVoices.
item.dc:creator: mpowel04

item.title: Amended Administrative Order on Consent: San Carlos Apache Tribe of the San Carlos Reservation

item.title: Elections for Region 9 Tribal Caucus 2017-2019
item.description:
• RTOC
    Home
  • Elections
    2017-19
  • Past
    Meetings
  • RTOC
    Charter
  • Contact
     
  • Strategic
    Plan
  • Docs
     

The Regional Tribal Operations Committee is soliciting nominations for representatives to serve on the Committee for the October 2017 to September 2019 term.

The RTOC is a working committee of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 9 and Federally Recognized Tribes in Arizona, California, and Nevada. The RTOC is co-chaired by the Director of the EPA Region 9 Land Division and an RTOC Tribal Representative selected by the Tribal Caucus. All tribes within Region 9 are members of the RTOC, but for organizational purposes, tribal leaders in each geographic area within the Region will nominate and later elect RTOC tribal representatives from the Tribal Caucus, as described in the RTOC Charter. This page will provide the election materials and updates on the election as we move through the process.

Tribal leaders may nominate a representative from your tribe or from another tribe in your area. Please ensure your nomination is returned to the EPA Region 9 by December 15, 2016. You may return the form by email (preferred) or regular mail, as detailed on the form.

Following receipt of nominations, formal ballots will be sent out by January 20, 2015. Ballots will be tallied and results will be announced by EPA Region 9 at the Spring RTOC meeting, scheduled for April 18-20, 2017 in San Francisco.

If you have any questions, please contact: Ruben Mojica-Hernandez (mojica-hernandez.ruben@epa.gov)

Nomination Form

EPA Region 9 Tribal RTOC Representative Nomination Form(1 pg, 16 K, 11/14/2016)

item.title: Solid Waste Program Budgeting for Alaska Tribal Communities
item.description:
Related Information

  • Roadmap for Funding Sustainable Solid Waste Programs in Rural Alaska
  • EPA's Region 10 Tribal Program

A beginner's guide: Step by step instructions on how to develop a budget for your solid waste utility

EPA developed this costing tool to help rural Alaska Tribes make a budget for their community's waste management program. We hope it will be useful for tribal environmental planners and directors, General Assistance Program (GAP) coordinators, solid waste managers, and others involved in developing solid waste budgets.

For more information, contact Kristine Carre (carre.kristine@epa.gov), 503-326-7024.

  • Solid Waste Program Budgeting for Alaska Tribal Communities (PDF)(64 pp, 3 MB, October 2016, EPA-910-K-16-002)
    (Costing Tool)

item.title: Memorandum of Understanding Regarding Interagency Coordination and Collaboration for the Protection of Tribal Treaty Rights
item.description:
This document is the federal interagency Memorandum of Understanding affirming protection of tribal treaty rights and similar tribal rights relating to natural resources when federal action is taken. It will be updated as additional federal agencies become signatories.

  • Tribal treaty rights interagency MOU (PDF)(13 pp, 715 K)
    Treaty rights MOU with updated list of signatories.
item.dc:creator: mpowel04

item.title: EPA’s Direct Implementation of Federal Environmental Programs in Indian Country
item.description:
• The EPA’s Direct Implementation of Federal Environmental Programs in Indian Country document describes EPA’s direct implementation responsibilities and activities under nine major federal environmental statutes and for emergency response activities. Each section describes the key direct implementation responsibilities that EPA retains.
  • EPA's Direct Implementation of Federal Environmental Programs in Indian Country (PDF)(31 pp, 604 K, 8/25/2016)
